name: Barbell Curl
description: The classic bicep exercise using a straight barbell to curl weight from arms extended to full contraction. This foundational movement allows for heavy loading and builds overall bicep mass.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, grip barbell at shoulder width
Start with arms fully extended, barbell at thighs
Keep elbows pinned at sides throughout movement
Curl bar up by flexing biceps until forearms are vertical
Squeeze at top, lower with control to full extension

name: EZ-Bar Curl
description: A bicep curl using an EZ-bar with angled grips that reduce wrist strain compared to straight barbell curls. The semi-supinated grip provides a comfortable alternative while still allowing substantial loading.
instructions: Grip EZ-bar on the angled portions, hands shoulder-width apart
Stand with arms extended, bar at thighs
Keep elbows fixed at sides throughout
Curl bar up to shoulder level by flexing biceps
Lower with control back to full arm extension

name: Preacher Curl
description: A bicep curl performed on a preacher bench with upper arms braced against the angled pad, eliminating momentum and isolating the biceps. The fixed position emphasizes the stretched portion of the movement.
instructions: Sit at preacher bench, armpits at top of pad
Grip EZ-bar or barbell with arms extended down the pad
Curl weight up while keeping upper arms on pad
Squeeze biceps at top of movement
Lower with control to full extension, maintaining pad contact

name: Drag Curl
description: A bicep curl variation where the barbell is dragged up along the body with elbows moving backward, keeping constant tension on the biceps and reducing front delt involvement.
instructions: Stand holding barbell at thighs with shoulder-width grip
Instead of curling forward, drag bar up along torso
Pull elbows back behind body as bar rises
Keep bar in contact with or close to body throughout
Lower by reversing the drag motion

name: Reverse Curl
description: A curl performed with an overhand (pronated) grip that shifts emphasis from the biceps to the brachioradialis and forearm extensors. This movement builds forearm size and grip strength.
instructions: Stand holding barbell with overhand grip, hands shoulder-width
Arms extended at thighs, palms facing down
Keep elbows at sides, curl bar up toward shoulders
Squeeze forearms at top of movement
Lower with control to full extension
formCues: Use lighter weight than regular curls

name: Standing Dumbbell Curl
description: The fundamental dumbbell bicep exercise performed standing, allowing for independent arm training and full supination. This versatile movement builds bicep size with freedom of wrist rotation.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells at sides, palms facing thighs
Keep elbows pinned at sides throughout
Curl weights up while rotating palms to face shoulders
Squeeze biceps at full contraction
Lower with control while rotating back to neutral

name: Seated Dumbbell Curl
description: A dumbbell curl performed seated on a bench, reducing the ability to use body momentum and providing better isolation. The seated position enforces stricter form than standing variations.
instructions: Sit on bench with back support, dumbbells at sides
Start with arms hanging straight, palms facing inward
Curl both dumbbells up, supinating as you lift
Squeeze biceps at peak contraction
Lower with control to starting position

name: Incline Dumbbell Curl
description: A dumbbell curl performed on an incline bench that places the biceps in a stretched position at the start, emphasizing the long head. The angle prevents cheating and maximizes bicep tension.
instructions: Set bench to 45-60 degree incline, sit with back against pad
Let arms hang straight down with dumbbells, palms forward
Keep upper arms stationary, curl weights toward shoulders
Squeeze at peak contraction
Lower slowly to full stretch at bottom

name: Hammer Curl
description: A curl performed with a neutral (palms facing) grip that targets the brachialis and brachioradialis along with the biceps. This variation builds arm thickness and forearm development.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells at sides, palms facing body (neutral grip)
Keep elbows pinned at sides throughout
Curl weights up while maintaining neutral grip
Squeeze at top of movement
Lower with control to full extension

name: Concentration Curl
description: A unilateral bicep curl performed seated with elbow braced against inner thigh, allowing complete focus on one arm at a time. This isolation movement maximizes mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Sit on bench, spread legs wide with feet flat
Brace back of working arm's elbow against inner thigh
Let dumbbell hang at full extension
Curl weight up toward shoulder, squeezing bicep
Lower with control, complete reps then switch arms

name: Zottman Curl
description: A comprehensive curl that combines supinated curling with pronated lowering, hitting both biceps and forearm extensors in one movement. The rotation at top provides complete arm development.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells at sides, palms facing forward
Curl weights up with palms facing you (supinated)
At top, rotate wrists so palms face down (pronated)
Lower weights slowly with overhand grip
At bottom, rotate back to palms forward and repeat

name: Spider Curl
description: A bicep curl performed face down on an incline bench with arms hanging straight down, eliminating all momentum and emphasizing the peak contraction of the biceps.
instructions: Lie face down on incline bench set to 45 degrees
Let arms hang straight down holding dumbbells or barbell
Curl weight up toward face, keeping upper arms still
Squeeze hard at peak contraction
Lower with control to full extension

name: Cross-Body Curl
description: A hammer-grip curl that travels across the body toward the opposite shoulder, emphasizing the brachialis and creating a unique angle of contraction for the biceps.
instructions: Stand with dumbbell in one hand, neutral grip
Curl dumbbell across body toward opposite shoulder
Keep elbow close to body throughout
Squeeze at top, lower with control
Complete reps then switch arms

name: Cable Curl
description: A bicep curl using a cable machine with straight bar attachment, providing constant tension throughout the entire range of motion. The cable eliminates dead spots found in free weight curls.
instructions: Attach straight bar to low cable, stand facing machine
Grip bar at shoulder width, arms extended
Keep elbows pinned at sides throughout
Curl bar up toward shoulders
Squeeze at top, lower with constant tension

name: Rope Cable Curl
description: A cable curl using a rope attachment that allows for neutral grip and wrist rotation through the movement. The rope enables spreading at the top for enhanced peak contraction.
instructions: Attach rope to low cable, grip with neutral palms-facing hold
Stand facing machine, arms extended down
Curl rope up while keeping elbows pinned
At top, spread rope ends apart for peak contraction
Lower with control to full extension

name: Single-Arm Cable Curl
description: A unilateral cable curl allowing focused work on each bicep independently with constant tension. This variation addresses strength imbalances and maximizes mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Attach D-handle to low cable, stand facing machine
Grip handle with working arm extended down
Keep elbow pinned at side throughout
Curl handle toward shoulder with full contraction
Lower with control, complete reps then switch arms

name: High Cable Curl
description: A cable curl performed with arms extended from high pulleys, curling toward the head in a double bicep pose position. This angle emphasizes the bicep peak and provides a unique contraction.
instructions: Stand between high cable pulleys with handles in each hand
Extend arms out to sides at shoulder height, slight elbow bend
Curl handles toward ears by flexing biceps
Squeeze hard in contracted position
Extend arms back to starting position with control

name: Lying Cable Curl
description: A cable curl performed lying on the floor with cable behind the head, providing maximum stretch on the biceps at the start position. This unique angle emphasizes the long head.
instructions: Lie on floor with head toward low cable, grip bar or rope
Extend arms behind head toward cable
Keep upper arms stationary, curl toward forehead
Squeeze biceps at peak contraction
Lower with control to full stretch

name: Bayesian Curl
description: A cable curl performed facing away from the machine with arm behind the body, maximizing stretch on the biceps long head. This exercise provides intense stretch-mediated hypertrophy stimulus.
instructions: Attach handle to low cable, stand facing away from machine
Hold handle with arm behind body, palm up
Keep upper arm stationary behind torso
Curl handle forward and up toward shoulder
Lower with control to full stretch behind body

name: Chin-Up
description: A compound pulling exercise using an underhand grip that emphasizes the biceps along with the back muscles. The supinated grip maximizes bicep involvement compared to overhand pull-ups.
instructions: Grip pull-up bar with underhand grip, hands shoulder-width
Hang with arms fully extended
Pull body up until chin clears the bar
Focus on squeezing biceps at the top
Lower with control to full arm extension

name: Band Curl
description: A bicep curl using a resistance band that provides increasing tension through the range of motion. This accessible exercise is perfect for home workouts and high-rep burnouts.
instructions: Stand on center of band, grip handles or ends
Start with arms extended at sides
Keep elbows pinned, curl hands toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at peak contraction
Lower with control against band resistance

name: Machine Curl
description: A bicep curl performed on a machine with a fixed movement path and built-in elbow support. This beginner-friendly option provides consistent resistance and eliminates the need for stabilization.
instructions: Adjust seat so elbows align with machine pivot point
Sit with arms on pad, grip handles
Curl handles toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at full contraction
Lower with control to starting position

name: Incline Hammer Curl
description: A hammer curl performed on an incline bench that increases the stretch on the brachialis and long head of the biceps. The incline position eliminates momentum and emphasizes the stretched portion.
instructions: Set bench to 45-60 degree incline, sit back
Let arms hang straight with dumbbells in neutral grip
Keep upper arms still, curl with palms facing each other
Squeeze at top, maintaining neutral grip throughout
Lower with control to full stretch

name: Dumbbell Preacher Curl
description: A unilateral preacher curl using a dumbbell for independent arm training on the preacher bench. This allows focus on each bicep separately while benefiting from the strict form of the preacher position.
instructions: Sit at preacher bench with one arm on pad
Hold dumbbell with arm fully extended on pad
Keep armpit at top of pad for proper position
Curl dumbbell up, squeezing bicep at top
Lower with control to full extension, complete reps then switch

name: Alternating Dumbbell Curl
description: A bicep curl performed alternating one arm at a time, extending time under tension and allowing focus on each arm independently. This variation provides continuous work while improving mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells at sides, palms facing thighs
Curl one dumbbell up while supinating (rotating palm up)
Lower the first dumbbell while curling the second
Maintain controlled alternating rhythm
Keep elbows pinned at sides throughout

name: Close-Grip Bench Press
description: A bench press variation with hands placed closer together to emphasize the triceps over the chest. This compound movement allows for heavy loading while building tricep mass and pressing strength.
instructions: Lie on bench, grip barbell with hands 8-12 inches apart
Unrack bar over chest, arms extended
Lower bar to lower chest with elbows tucked at 45 degrees
Touch chest lightly, press back up explosively
Lock out fully at top, squeezing triceps

name: Diamond Push-Up
description: A push-up variation with hands placed close together forming a diamond shape, dramatically increasing tricep involvement. This bodyweight exercise is excellent for building tricep strength and endurance.
instructions: Start in push-up position with hands together, forming diamond with index fingers and thumbs
Keep body in straight line from head to heels
Lower chest toward hands, elbows tracking close to body
Descend until chest nearly touches hands
Press back up to full arm extension

name: Tricep Dips
description: A compound bodyweight exercise performed on parallel bars with an upright torso to emphasize the triceps over the chest. This challenging movement builds significant tricep mass and strength.
instructions: Grip parallel bars, jump up to straight arm support
Keep torso upright, don't lean forward
Lower body by bending elbows until upper arms parallel to floor
Keep elbows close to body, pointing back
Press back up to full lockout

name: JM Press
description: A hybrid movement between close-grip bench press and skull crusher that heavily targets the triceps while allowing heavier loads. Named after powerlifter JM Blakley who popularized this exercise.
instructions: Lie on bench with close grip on barbell
Lower bar toward upper chest/throat area
Allow elbows to drift forward during descent
Bar path is between bench press and skull crusher
Press back up by extending elbows to lockout

name: Board Press
description: A bench press variation with boards placed on the chest to limit range of motion, emphasizing the lockout portion where triceps are most active. Common in powerlifting for building tricep strength.
instructions: Lie on bench with close to moderate grip
Have partner hold 2-4 boards on chest
Lower bar to touch boards, pause briefly
Press explosively to full lockout
Focus on tricep drive through sticking point

name: Barbell Skull Crusher
description: A lying tricep extension lowering a barbell toward the forehead or behind the head, providing an intense stretch and contraction. This classic tricep builder targets all three heads.
instructions: Lie on bench holding barbell with narrow grip, arms extended over chest
Keep upper arms stationary, pointing at ceiling
Lower bar toward forehead or just behind head by bending elbows
Feel stretch in triceps at bottom
Extend elbows to press bar back to start
formCues: Lower behind head for more stretch

name: Dumbbell Skull Crusher
description: A lying tricep extension using dumbbells that allows independent arm movement and various grip positions. The dumbbells provide freedom of motion and address strength imbalances.
instructions: Lie on bench holding dumbbells with arms extended, palms facing each other
Keep upper arms vertical and stationary
Lower dumbbells toward temples or behind head by bending elbows
Stretch triceps at bottom of movement
Extend elbows to press dumbbells back up

name: Dumbbell Overhead Tricep Extension
description: A seated or standing extension holding a dumbbell overhead and lowering it behind the head. This exercise emphasizes the long head of the triceps through the stretched overhead position.
instructions: Hold one dumbbell with both hands, pressing it overhead
Keep upper arms close to head, pointing up
Lower dumbbell behind head by bending elbows
Feel stretch in triceps at bottom
Extend elbows to press dumbbell back overhead

name: Cable Overhead Tricep Extension
description: An overhead tricep extension using a cable for constant tension throughout the movement. The cable resistance provides smooth resistance and excellent stretch on the long head.
instructions: Attach rope or bar to high pulley, face away from machine
Step forward, lean slightly, hold attachment overhead
Keep upper arms fixed next to head
Extend elbows to press attachment forward
Lower with control to feel stretch behind head

name: Barbell Overhead Tricep Extension
description: An overhead tricep extension using a barbell or EZ-bar, allowing heavier loading than dumbbell versions. This exercise emphasizes the long head and builds substantial tricep mass.
instructions: Hold barbell overhead with narrow grip, arms extended
Keep upper arms close to head throughout
Lower bar behind head by bending elbows
Descend until feeling full tricep stretch
Extend elbows to press bar back overhead

name: Rope Tricep Pushdown
description: A cable tricep extension using a rope attachment that allows the wrists to rotate and spread at the bottom for peak contraction. This popular exercise provides constant tension and excellent tricep pump.
instructions: Attach rope to high cable, grip ends with neutral grip
Keep elbows pinned at sides, forearms parallel to floor
Push rope down by extending elbows
At bottom, spread rope ends apart for extra contraction
Return with control to starting position

name: Straight Bar Pushdown
description: A cable tricep extension using a straight bar attachment that allows for slightly heavier loading than rope variations. The fixed bar position emphasizes the lateral head of the triceps.
instructions: Attach straight bar to high cable
Grip bar with overhand grip, shoulder-width or narrower
Keep elbows pinned at sides
Push bar down until arms fully extended
Return with control, keeping tension

name: V-Bar Pushdown
description: A cable tricep extension using a V-shaped bar attachment that provides a neutral grip angle. This variation is comfortable on the wrists while allowing good loading.
instructions: Attach V-bar to high cable
Grip bar with palms facing each other
Keep elbows pinned at sides
Push bar down to full arm extension
Return with control, maintaining elbow position

name: Single-Arm Pushdown
description: A unilateral cable tricep extension allowing focus on each arm independently. This exercise addresses strength imbalances and maximizes mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Attach D-handle to high cable
Stand with working side toward machine
Keep elbow pinned at side
Push handle down to full extension
Return with control, complete reps then switch

name: Tricep Kickback
description: A dumbbell isolation exercise extending the arm backward while bent over, maximizing tricep contraction at full extension. This movement emphasizes the peak contraction of the triceps.
instructions: Bend forward at hips, support on bench if needed
Hold dumbbell with upper arm parallel to floor, elbow at 90 degrees
Extend arm straight back by straightening elbow
Squeeze tricep hard at full extension
Lower with control back to 90 degrees

name: French Press
description: A seated or lying tricep extension lowering weight behind the head with elbows pointing up, emphasizing the long head. This classic exercise provides excellent stretch and contraction.
instructions: Sit or lie holding barbell or EZ-bar overhead
Keep elbows pointing up throughout movement
Lower weight behind head by bending elbows
Feel full stretch in triceps at bottom
Press back to starting position

name: Tate Press
description: A lying dumbbell tricep exercise where elbows flare out and dumbbells are lowered to the chest in an arcing motion. Named after powerlifter Dave Tate, this targets the triceps from a unique angle.
instructions: Lie on bench holding dumbbells over chest, arms extended
Point elbows outward, palms facing feet
Lower dumbbells toward chest by bending elbows outward
Dumbbells touch or nearly touch chest at bottom
Press back up by extending elbows

name: Bench Dips
description: A bodyweight tricep exercise using a bench or chair with hands behind body and feet on the floor. This accessible exercise is easier than parallel bar dips while still effectively targeting the triceps.
instructions: Sit on bench edge, hands gripping edge beside hips
Slide forward off bench, supporting weight on hands
Keep feet flat on floor, legs bent or extended
Lower body by bending elbows to about 90 degrees
Press back up to full arm extension

name: Ring Dips
description: An advanced dip variation performed on gymnastic rings that adds significant instability challenge. The rings require intense stabilization effort while building exceptional tricep and pressing strength.
instructions: Mount rings, pressing up to straight arm support
Turn rings out at top (RTO) for full lockout
Lower body by bending elbows, controlling ring movement
Descend until upper arms parallel to floor
Press back up to full lockout with rings turned out

name: Band Pushdown
description: A tricep pushdown using a resistance band anchored overhead, providing accommodating resistance. This accessible exercise is perfect for home workouts and warm-ups.
instructions: Anchor band above head height
Grip band with both hands at chest level
Keep elbows pinned at sides
Push hands down until arms fully extended
Return with control, keeping band tension

name: Machine Tricep Extension
description: A tricep extension performed on a machine with fixed movement path and handles. This beginner-friendly option provides consistent resistance with built-in support.
instructions: Adjust seat and handles for proper alignment
Grip handles, elbows bent at starting position
Push handles down/forward by extending elbows
Squeeze triceps at full extension
Return with control to starting position

name: Close-Grip Push-Up
description: A push-up variation with hands placed closer together than standard, increasing tricep involvement while maintaining chest and shoulder engagement. An accessible bodyweight tricep builder.
instructions: Start in push-up position with hands closer than shoulder width
Keep body in straight line from head to heels
Lower chest toward floor, keeping elbows close to body
Descend until chest nearly touches floor
Push back up to full arm extension

name: Cable Kickback
description: A tricep kickback using a cable for constant tension throughout the movement. The cable provides resistance in both directions unlike the dumbbell version.
instructions: Attach handle to low cable, bend forward and grab
Keep upper arm parallel to floor
Extend arm backward by straightening elbow
Squeeze tricep at full extension
Return with control, complete reps then switch

name: Single-Arm Overhead Dumbbell Extension
description: A unilateral overhead tricep extension using one dumbbell at a time, allowing focused work on each arm. This exercise maximizes long head stretch while addressing strength imbalances.
instructions: Stand or sit holding one dumbbell overhead, arm extended
Keep upper arm close to head, pointing up
Lower dumbbell behind head by bending elbow
Feel stretch in tricep at bottom
Extend elbow to press back up, then switch arms

name: Lying Dumbbell Tricep Extension
description: A tricep extension performed lying on the floor or bench with dumbbells, providing a stable base for focused tricep work. The floor version eliminates excessive stretch that can stress the elbow.
instructions: Lie on back holding dumbbells with arms extended over chest
Keep upper arms stationary, perpendicular to floor
Lower dumbbells toward shoulders by bending elbows
Stop just before touching shoulders
Extend elbows to press dumbbells back up
